Title: Parcellation of cortical afferents to three distinct sectors in the parahippocampal gyrus of the rhesus monkey: An anatomical and neurophysiological study
Abstract: The posterior parahippocampal gyrus (PHG) of the rhesus monkey (Macaca mulatta) is comprised of three distinct cortical areas based on cytoarchitecture, connectivity, and neurophysiological response properties. Fluorescent retrograde tracers placed in each PHG area demonstrated unique patterns of cortical afferent input to areas TH, TL, and TF. Area TF receives inputs from the multimodal cortices of the superior temporal sulcus including areas PGa, TPO, and MST, from the visuospatial parietal area PG-Opt, and from visual areas V3A and dorsal V4. Area TL receives afferents from the inferotemporal region including visual areas TE1 and TE2 as well as from areas TEa, IPa, and FST in the lower bank and depth of the superior temporal sulcus. In contrast, the input to area TH is from the rostral part of superior temporal gyrus, including the auditory association areas TS1-3, and from the middle sector of area TPO in the superior temporal sulcus. Frontal and cingulate areas also project to the PHG in largely differential patterns. To further investigate this a correlative electrophysiological study of the three PHG areas resulted in a confirmation of these differential cortical inputs such that visually responsive neurons were found in areas TF and TL, auditory responsive neurons or bimodal auditory/visual-responsive neurons in area TH, and somatosensory-responsive neurons at the TF/TL border. Since each PHG area also receives differential hippocampal input, these data suggest that the processing of unimodal or multimodal information may be related to memory processing functions that are largely segregated within areas TH, TL, and TF.

@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Citation: "In the temporal lobe, discrete clusters of labeled neurons were found in the rostral part of the superior temporal gyrus, including areas TS2 and TS3, and in the middle sector of area TPO in superior temporal sulcus (STS). On the medial surface, in the cingulate gyrus, neurons were found rostrally in area 24a and caudally in areas 23, 31, and in RSpl areas 29 and 30."

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Previous parcellation of areas TF, TH, TL by the same authors are conirmed in this study.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: Previous parcellation of areas TF, TH, TL by the same authors are conirmed in this study.

@Injections.Citation: "In case #1 the DY injection was placed into the rostral portion of TH just caudal to the junction of areas 28 and 35 (Figs. 3B, 6C)"
@Injections.Comments: Volume tracer per animal not specified

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "As shown in Figure 6, caudal to the injection site three bands of labeled neurons were observed in areas TH, TL, and TF. Rostral to the injection site, labeled neurons were found in area 28 and in the temporal polar cortex (area Pro). Ventromedially, clusters of neurons were labeled in the medial part of CA1 sector of the hippocampus and in the presubiculum (sections 2-4 in Fig. 6). In the temporal lobe, discrete clusters of labeled neurons were found in the rostral part of the superior temporal gyrus, including areas TS2 and TS3, and in the middle sector of area TPO in superior temporal sulcus (STS). On the medial surface, in the cingulate gyrus, neurons were found rostrally in area 24a and caudally in areas 23, 31, and in RSpl areas 29 and 30. Labeled neurons were also found in ventromedial prefrontal area. Some labeled neurons were also seen in the rostral part of the claustrum (not illustrated)."

@Injections.Citation: "In case #7, however, the DY injection was in area TFO and extended caudally into area 19."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In case #7, however, the DY injection was in area TFO and extended caudally into area 19. In this case, some of the labeling patterns were similar to the area TF injection in case #5, including labeled neurons in extrastriate areas dorsal V4, FST, MST, and in the lateral intraparietal area LIP. Labeled neurons were also present in multimodal area TPO and in retrosplenial cortex. Additionally, in this case (#7) labeled cells were observed in areas V3A and ventral V3. The labeled neurons in these latter two areas may be the result of involvement of area 19."

@Injections.Citation: "In case #8 a DY injection was placed into the rostral part of the PHG, mainly involving area TLr with a very minor encroachment into area 35 (Figs. 3B, 7C). Similar to the previously described injection in the caudal part of area TL (case #2), caudally there were three medial-lateral streams of labeled neurons in areas TH, TL, and TF (Fig. 7). More rostrally, labeled neurons were observed in TLr. Medial to the injection site, labeled neurons were found in area 28, prorhinal cortex, and area 35. In the hippocampus, labeled neurons were found in the CA1 subfield (sections 3-5 in Fig. 7) and some cells were labeled in the amygdala (see drawing B and section 2 in Fig. 7). Within the inferotemporal area, labeled neurons were observed in areas TE1 and TE2 as well as in area TEa in the lower bank of the STS. In the upper bank of the STS, labeled neurons were noted in area PGa. A discrete cluster of labeled neurons was observed in the insula and some labeled neurons were also seen in the rostral part of the claustrum."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Similar to the previously described injection in the caudal part of area TL (case #2), caudally there were three medial-lateral streams of labeled neurons in areas TH, TL, and TF (Fig. 7). More rostrally, labeled neurons were observed in TLr. Medial to the injection site, labeled neurons were found in area 28, prorhinal cortex, and area 35. In the hippocampus, labeled neurons were found in the CA1 subfield (sections 3-5 in Fig. 7) and some cells were labeled in the amygdala (see drawing B and section 2 in Fig. 7). Within the inferotemporal area, labeled neurons were observed in areas TE1 and TE2 as well as in area TEa in the lower bank of the STS. In the upper bank of the STS, labeled neurons were noted in area PGa. A discrete cluster of labeled neurons was observed in the insula and some labeled neurons were also seen in the rostral part of the claustrum. No labeled neurons were found in cingulate gyrus, in contrast to the area TF and area TH cases (Figs. 4, 6)."

@Injections.Citation: "In addition, FRT injections were placed in neighboring areas as controls, including laterally adjacent area TE1 (cases #10 and 11) and medially adjacent entorhinal cortex (case #12)."

@Methods_Animals.Comments: No detailed information about the animals is given

@Injections.Citation: "In case #2, an FB injection involved area TL near the caudal tip of the rhinal fissure "

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "As shown in Figure 5, caudal to the injection site labeled cells were found in areas TH, TL, and in both the medial and lateral banks of the occipitotemporal sulcus, including area TF. Rostrally, labeled neurons were found in area TLr and these extended all the way up to the temporal pole, including temporal proisocortex (Pro). Another stream of labeled neurons was found in the caudal half of perirhinal area 35 and in most of entorhinal cortex area 28. Ventromedially, labeled cells were clustered in the CA1 sector of the hippocampus (sections 4 and 5 in Fig. 5), and a few cells were found in the amygdala (not shown). Within the inferotemporal region, labeled neurons were found in areas TE1 and TE2 as well as in areas TEa, IPa, and FST in the lower bank and depth of the superior temporal sulcus. Few labeled neurons were noted in insular cortex. On the medial surface, labeled neurons were found at the junction of the anterior and posterior cingulate areas 24/23. A few labeled neurons were found in the most anterior part of the cingulate gyrus, area 25, as well as in orbital frontal area 13. Some labeled neurons were also seen in the rostral part of the claustrum (not shown)."

@Injections.Citation: "In case #3, an FB injection was placed into the caudal (posterior) part of the PHG at the junction of areas THO and TLO (Figs. 3B, 8C)"

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "As shown in Figure 8, caudal to the injection site labeled neurons were found in areas THO, TLO, and TFO, with few neurons extending in the ventral part of area 19 (ventral V4). Rostral to the injection site, labeled neurons were found in areas TH, TL, and some in area TF. There were a significant number of labeled neurons in areas 28, 35, and in temporal pole proisocortex (Pro). Ventromedially, labeled neurons were seen in the CA1 subfield and in the presubiculum (sections 1-3 in Fig. 8). Laterally, labeled cells were observed in areas PGa, TPO, and MST in the upper bank of the STS and in areas FST and MT in the depth and in the lower bank of the STS. Significant labeling was found in areas PG-Opt and dorsal V4. On the medial surface, labeled neurons were found in areas 23, 31, and in retrosplenial cortex extending up to the rostral tip of the calcarine sulcus. Additionally, labeled neurons were found in areas PGm and medial 19. In the frontal lobe a discrete cluster of labeled neurons was observed in the depths of the sulcus principalis involving area 46. Similar to the other four cases described, labeled neurons were also seen in the rostral part of the claustrum. This injection in THO/TLO takes on characteristics of a pattern typical of area TF/TFO (see case #5 in Fig. 4), suggesting that area TFO may bend medially at the caudal border with area 19."

@Injections.Citation: "In case #5, an FB injection was placed in the rostral part of area TF, involved the gyral portion of area TF, and extended into the rostral-medial bank of the occipitotemporal sulcus (Figs. 3B, 4C). "

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In case #5, an FB injection was placed in the rostral part of area TF, involved the gyral portion of area TF, and extended into the rostral-medial bank of the occipitotemporal sulcus (Figs. 3B, 4C)"

"Two additional cases were in area TL, one restricted to caudal area TL (red bead injection in case #4) placed between two previously described cases (cases #2 and #3), and one in area TLr (case #9), a fast blue injection that spread into area Pro in the temporal pole and into rostral area 35. The labeled neurons from the red bead injection in case #4 agreed with the pattern of labeling from the TLr/35 case (case #8) and the caudal TL case (case #2). Case #9 produced a variable pattern of neuronal labeling due to the spread of FRT into neighboring areas."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: No specific labeling patterns described, no figures either.

@Injections.Citation: "Two additional cases were in area TL, one restricted to caudal area TL (red bead injection in case #4) placed between two previously described cases..."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Two additional cases were in area TL, one restricted to caudal area TL (red bead injection in case #4) placed between two previously described cases (cases #2 and #3)[...]The labeled neurons from the red bead injection in case #4 agreed with the pattern of labeling from the TLr/35 case (case #8) and the caudal TL case (case #2)"
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: No specific labelling patterns described, no figures either.

@Injections.Citation: "In case #6, red beads were injected into area TF just caudal to the fast blue injection site in the previously described area TF case #5."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In case #6, red beads were injected into area TF just caudal to the fast blue injection site in the previously described area TF case #5. Although the transport of the red beads was limited, the patterns of labeled neurons agreed with those from case #5."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: No specific labelling patterns described, no figures either.

@Injections.Citation: "Four control cases involved placement of FRT into surrounding areas to the PHG but not within the PHG. One of these cases (#12) was in the caudal part of entorhinal cortex, mainly in area 28s, with some spread into area 28m; two cases were in TE1, case #10 in rostral TE1 and case #11 in caudal TE1;"

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Four control cases involved placement of FRT into surrounding areas to the PHG but not within the PHG. One of these cases (#12) was in the caudal part of entorhinal cortex, mainly in area 28s, with some spread into area 28m; two cases were in TE1, case #10 in rostral TE1 and case #11 in caudal TE1; and the last case (#13) was in perirhinal area 35 that spread into prorhinal and rostral entorhinal cortex. None of these four control cases had a resemblance to the cortical projection patterns demonstrated in the illustrated PHG cases in Figures 4-8. It should be pointed out that the transport of red and green beads was equal to the transport of the FB and DY with regard to retrograde labeling of local projection neurons. Although the distant projection neurons following a red or green bead injection had a similar labeling pattern compared to FB or DY, there were fewer labeled neurons."

One of these cases (#12) was in the caudal part of entorhinal cortex, mainly in area 28s, with some spread into area 28m; two cases were in TE1, case #10 in rostral TE1 and case #11 in caudal TE1; and the last case (#13) was in perirhinal area 35 that spread into prorhinal and rostral entorhinal cortex. publication.title: Parcellation of cortical afferents to three distinct sectors in the parahippocampal gyrus of the rhesus monkey: An anatomical and neurophysiological study
publication.abstract: The posterior parahippocampal gyrus (PHG) of the rhesus monkey (Macaca mulatta) is comprised of three distinct cortical areas based on cytoarchitecture, connectivity, and neurophysiological response properties. Fluorescent retrograde tracers placed in each PHG area demonstrated unique patterns of cortical afferent input to areas TH, TL, and TF. Area TL receives afferents from the inferotemporal region including visual areas TE1 and TE2 as well as from areas TEa, IPa, and FST in the lower bank and depth of the superior temporal sulcus. In contrast, the input to area TH is from the rostral part of superior temporal gyrus, including the auditory association areas TS1-3, and from the middle sector of area TPO in the superior temporal sulcus. Frontal and cingulate areas also project to the PHG in largely differential patterns. To further investigate this a correlative electrophysiological study of the three PHG areas resulted in a confirmation of these differential cortical inputs such that visually responsive neurons were found in areas TF and TL, auditory responsive neurons or bimodal auditory/visual-responsive neurons in area TH, and somatosensory-responsive neurons at the TF/TL border. Since each PHG area also receives differential hippocampal input, these data suggest that the processing of unimodal or multimodal information may be related to memory processing functions that are largely segregated within areas TH, TL, and TF.
